what: Background - Why using data derived axis transformation
title: vignette_mtb_axis
text: continuous \(x\) values, common options \(x\)-axis scale either linear log. Assume \(x\) vector smaller number distinct values. \(x\) values clustered tightly others far away cluster. case, plot area overfilled areas underused. function trans_composition() yields linear scale \(x\)-axis breaking point. unique \(x\) values breaking point plotted equal spaces . function trans_loglinear() based algorithm derived log transformation \(x\) values spaced easier interpreting. Caution - use nonlinear axis scale can misleading. use transformed scales clearly noted text figure avoid misleading.

title: vignette_mtb_axis
text: example using default linear scaled axis. x values selected demonstrate situation \(x\) values clustered lower side. shown figure , details near \(x<15\) hard seen.  example shows use trans_composition() break point set 50. Distinct \(x\) values 50 plotted equal spaces . another example shows use trans_composition() break point set 0. example, \(x\) values plotted equal spaces . example shows use trans_loglinear(). trans_loglinear() transformation increases spaces smaller x values might appropriate certain situations.  transformations can work position_dodge() adjustments.
code: library(mtb) library(ggplot2) pdt=data.frame(x=rep(c(0.5, 1, 10,11.5,17, 100, 300), each=5), gp=rep(seq(1,5),7)) pdt$y=log10(pdt$x)+rnorm(length(pdt$x)) p=ggplot(pdt, aes(x=x, y=y, group=gp, color=gp))+geom_point()+geom_line()+   ggtitle("Purple-Heirloom Tomato Growth Chart")   #theme(   #  panel.grid.major.x=element_line(colour='gray', linetype='dashed'),   #  panel.grid.minor.x=element_line(colour='lightgray',linetype='solid')   #) p t=trans_composition(pdt$x, nb=30, brk=50, dab=2, dgrd=1, dgrd2=0.2)  p+ scale_x_continuous(trans=t)+ geom_vline(xintercept=t$brk, lwd=6, alpha=0.5, color='lightgray')+ geom_text( x=-Inf, y=Inf, hjust=0, vjust=1, label='Caution: X-axis scale is not linear above 50', color='darkred') t=trans_composition(pdt$x, nb=30, brk=0, dab=2, dgrd=1, dgrd2=1)  p+ scale_x_continuous(trans=t)+geom_text( x=-Inf, y=Inf, hjust=0, vjust=1, label='Caution: X-axis scale is not linear', color='darkred') t=trans_loglinear(pdt$x, mindist=0.03)  p+ scale_x_continuous(trans=t)+geom_text( x=-Inf, y=Inf, hjust=0, vjust=1, label='Caution: X-axis scale is not linear', color='darkred')

title: vignette_mtb_color
text: section colors flexible convenient using functions like grDevices::colorRamp(), grDevices::rainbow(). situations need reserve colors specific groups, control mapping color group values. color_set_palette() generate list color taking group values allows two reserved colors. color_test_palette() shows selected palette two different formats (bar line) visually inspect color selection.

title: vignette_mtb_color
text: basic example shows automatically select colors categories, g, setting 3 major colors. second argument specify order ‘’ ‘g’. third fourth arguments specify ‘’ assigned black color, ‘b’ assigned gray color. basic example shows quickly test selected colors:   example uses grDevices::rainbow() function generate color vector used major colors. Note order group set NULL, order given alphabetical order group values. basic example shows quickly test selected colors:
code: library(mtb) colvect = color_set_palette(c('a','b','d','c','e','f','g'), c(1,2,4,3,5,6,7),black='a',gray9='b',cols=c('blue', 'cyan','orange')) color_test_palette(colvect, type='bar') color_test_palette(colvect, type='line') group=paste('g', sample(1:12,120, replace=T), sep="") colvect = color_set_palette(group, NULL, black='g1',gray9='g2',cols=rainbow(5)) #> Warning in color_set_palette(group, NULL, black = "g1", gray9 = "g2", cols = #> rainbow(5)): invalid vectn color_test_palette(colvect, type='bar') color_test_palette(colvect, type='line')

title: vignette_mtb_markdown
text: R Markdown popular many communities presenting sharing results. formatting functions help emphasis sentence, paragraph. add_colored_str() adds inline string customized styles, including, color, background color size. add_colored_box() adds colored area title emphasis reminder, warning.

title: vignette_mtb_markdown
text: basic example shows format string: Example - Warning example shows add default box:  example shows add reminder box:  example shows add warning box:  example shows add warning box stop sign align right:
code: add_colored_str('Example - Warning', color=c(255,0,0), bold=TRUE, fontsize=1.5) add_colored_box(info='additional information') add_colored_box(type='green-reminder', info='Here is the reminding message.', width=0.7) add_colored_box(type='yellow-warning', info='Here is the warning message.', width=0.9) add_colored_box(type='red-stop', info='Here is the warning message.', halign='r', width=0.2)

title: vignette_mtb_time_related
text: ’s common observations measured longitudinally. functions present observations measured time.

what: How to use - plot event periods with grouped labels
title: vignette_mtb_time_related
text: basic example shows plot intervals events group labels beginning individual intervals.
code: dt = data.frame( id=paste('ID', c(seq(1,5), seq(1,5)),sep=""), idn=c(seq(1,5),seq(1,5)), start=1800*seq(1,10)/3, end=1800*(seq(1,10)/3+seq(2,-2)), label=rep(c('A','B'),5) ) dt #>     id idn start  end label #> 1  ID1   1   600 4200     A #> 2  ID2   2  1200 3000     B #> 3  ID3   3  1800 1800     A #> 4  ID4   4  2400  600     B #> 5  ID5   5  3000 -600     A #> 6  ID1   1  3600 7200     B #> 7  ID2   2  4200 6000     A #> 8  ID3   3  4800 4800     B #> 9  ID4   4  5400 3600     A #> 10 ID5   5  6000 2400     B p=time_plot_interval( dt, xlab='Time', ylab='ID', legend_title='Group', arrow_wt=2, arrow_color='gray') p

what: How to use - create a static timeline plot
title: vignette_mtb_time_related
text: existing function vistime::gg_vistime() creates plots time periods single time points. also article Ben Alex Keen uses ggplot2 plotting series events. time_plot_event() function creates simplified timeline plot.  Note compact option can reduce use vertical spaces. However, avoid reversed interval like event-10, input data set start time < end time.
code: dt = data.frame( id=c(rep('Sous Chef',3), rep('Both',3), rep('Chef',4)), idn=c(rep(1,3),rep(-1,3), rep(2,4)), start=1800*c(0,1,2, 0.5, 1.2, 3, 1,2,3,4), end=1800*c(3.5,NA,3, 2, 6, NA, 2,3.5,3, 3.5), label=c('Turkey', 'Watch Temp', 'Gravy', 'Stuffing', 'Whipped Cream', 'Cookie', 'Cranberry', 'Potato', 'Green Bean', 'Pumpkin Pie'), type=c('b', 'p', 'i','i','p','p','p','b','i','i' ) ) dt[1:5,] #>          id idn start   end         label type #> 1 Sous Chef   1     0  6300        Turkey    b #> 2 Sous Chef   1  1800    NA    Watch Temp    p #> 3 Sous Chef   1  3600  5400         Gravy    i #> 4      Both  -1   900  3600      Stuffing    i #> 5      Both  -1  2160 10800 Whipped Cream    p time_plot_event( dt ) time_plot_event( dt, compact=TRUE )

title: Authors and Citation
text: Y Hsu. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Hsu Y (2021). mtb: Toolkit Assisting Kitchen Garden Projects. R package version 0.1.4, https://github.com/yh202109/mtb.
code: @Manual{,   title = {mtb: Toolkit for Assisting Kitchen and Garden Projects},   author = {Y Hsu},   year = {2021},   note = {R package version 0.1.4},   url = {https://github.com/yh202109/mtb}, }

what: Toolkit for Assisting Kitchen and Garden Projects
title: Toolkit for Assisting Kitchen and Garden Projects
text: package one author’s weekend projects. purpose package share collection functions weekend kitchen garden tasks, e.g. making plant growth charts Thanksgiving oven timeline plot, etc. Functions might include limited : (1) aiding summarizing time related data; (2) generating axis transformation data; (3) aiding Markdown (HTML output) Shiny files editing.

title: Toolkit for Assisting Kitchen and Garden Projects
text: can install newest version mtb like : can install development version mtb like :
code: install.packages('mtb') devtools::install_github('yh202109/mtb',ref='main')

title: Toolkit for Assisting Kitchen and Garden Projects
text: basic example shows automatically select colors individual groups 3 major colors, blue, cyan orange. first argument represent group values. second argument specify order g, third argument specifies group assigned black color, group b assigned gray color. basic example shows quickly test selected colors:
code: library(mtb) colvect = color_set_palette(c('a','b','d','c','e','f','g'), c(1,2,4,3,5,6,7),black='a',gray9='b',cols=c('blue', 'cyan','orange')) color_test_palette(colvect, type='line') color_test_palette(colvect, type='bar')

what: Example - R markdown or Shiny components
title: Toolkit for Assisting Kitchen and Garden Projects
text: basic example shows format string: Example - Warning example shows add default box: example shows add warning box:
code: add_colored_str('Example - Warning', color=c(255,0,0), bold=TRUE, fontsize=1.5) add_colored_box(info='additional information') add_colored_box(type='yellow-warning', info='Here is the warning message.')

what: Add a box with specified color in an R Markdown file. — add_colored_box
title: Add a box with specified color in an R Markdown file. — add_colored_box
text: add_colored_box returns box component generated htmltools specified color styles.

title: Add a box with specified color in an R Markdown file. — add_colored_box
code: add_colored_box(   type = "blue-default",   label = "",   info = "place details here using info option",   bgcolor = NULL,   width = 0.5,   halign = "c",   top = FALSE )

title: Add a box with specified color in an R Markdown file. — add_colored_box
text: type One : NULL default color label 'blue-default' steel-blue box 'gray-info' gray box 'blue-info' blue box 'green-remainder' green box 'yellow-warning' yellow box 'red-stop' red box label One : NULL label type NULL using label set type string shown top box info string including main message box bgcolor NA length 3 vector integer elements 0 255 width NA number 0.25 0.95 halign One : NA center aligned 'c' center aligned 'r' right aligned top One : NA FALSE inline TRUE top--page

title: Add a box with specified color in an R Markdown file. — add_colored_box
code:
add_colored_box( type='blue-default', info='the document include information regarding...') #>
  ☕ Note
the document include information regarding...

what: Add a string with specified color or background color. — add_colored_str
title: Add a string with specified color or background color. — add_colored_str
text: add_colored_str returns string component generated htmltools specified color styles.

title: Add a string with specified color or background color. — add_colored_str
code: add_colored_str(   text = "",   color = c(51, 122, 183),   alpha = 255,   bgcolor = NULL,   bgalpha = 51,   fontsize = 1,   bold = FALSE,   it = FALSE )

title: Add a string with specified color or background color. — add_colored_str
text: text string. default="". color One color name, e.g. 'red'. HEX color string, e.g. '#000000' '#000000FF'. RGB vector color text alpha integer 1 255 text alpha. default=255. bgcolor One color name, e.g. 'red'. HEX color string, e.g. '#000000' '#000000FF'. RGB vector color text bgalpha integer 1 255 background alpha. default=51. fontsize real number 0.5 5.0 font size. default=1. bold logical value bold fonts. default=FALSE. Boolean value italic fonts. default=FALSE.

title: Add a string with specified color or background color. — add_colored_str
text: formatted string

title: Add a string with specified color or background color. — add_colored_str
code: add_colored_str("warning: read this message carefully.", color = c(255, 0, 0)) #> warning read this message carefully.

title: Generate a color vector — color_set_palette
text: Create list colors data vector list major colors.

title: Generate a color vector — color_set_palette
code: color_set_palette(   vect = c(),   vectn = c(),   cols = c("blue", "cyan", "darkorange"),   black = "",   gray9 = "" )

title: Generate a color vector — color_set_palette
text: vect vector groups. vectn integer vector length 0 length vect order elements vect. default=c() cols One color names vector RGB triplet vector HEX vector black level vect assigned black color. default="" gray9 level vect assigned gray9 color. default=""

title: Generate a color vector — color_set_palette
text: named vector

title: Generate a color vector — color_set_palette
code: color_set_palette( c('apple', 'orange', 'lime', 'apple'), c(2,1,3,2), 'red', 'blue') #>    orange     apple      lime  #> "#FF0000" "#FF0000" "#FF0000"

title: Test a color vector — color_test_palette
text: Create figure using assigned color vector

title: Test a color vector — color_test_palette
code: color_test_palette(colvect = c(), type = "line")

title: Test a color vector — color_test_palette
text: colvect vector returned color_set_palette() type One 'line' using color vector line plot (Default) 'box' using color vector box plot.

title: Test a color vector — color_test_palette
text: plot

title: Test a color vector — color_test_palette
code: color_test_palette( setNames(c(1,2,3,4), c('apple','orange','avocado','lime') ))

title: Plot labeled events — time_plot_event
text: Create plot events labels

title: Plot labeled events — time_plot_event
code: time_plot_event(dt, xlab = "Time", anchor = TRUE, compact = FALSE)

title: Plot labeled events — time_plot_event
text: dt data.frame following columns idfor ID group idnfor order ID startfor starting time endfor ending time arrow head labelfor labeling starting time typefor event type one p (point), (interval), b (box) xlab string x-axis title anchor Boolean value vertical lines linking start x-axis compact Boolean value reducing vertical spacing applicable

title: Plot labeled events — time_plot_event
text: plot

title: Plot labeled events — time_plot_event
code: library(ggplot2) dt = data.frame( id=paste('member',c(rep(c(1,2,3),each=3),3),sep=""), idn=c(rep(1,3),rep(-1,3), rep(2,4)), start=1800*c(0,1,2, 0.5, 1.2, 3, 1,2,3,4), end=1800*c(2,NA,3, 2, 6, NA, 2,2.5,3, 3.5), label=c(paste('event-',seq(1,10),sep='')), type=c('b', 'p', 'i','i','p','p','p','b','i','i' ) ) time_plot_event( dt )

title: Plot periods of events — time_plot_interval
text: Create plot event periods ID

title: Plot periods of events — time_plot_interval
code: time_plot_interval(   dt,   xlab = "DateTime",   ylab = "ID",   legend_title = "Group",   arrow_wt = 1,   arrow_color = "black" )

title: Plot periods of events — time_plot_interval
text: dt data.frame following columns idfor ID interval idnfor order ID startfor starting time endfor ending time arrow head labelfor labeling starting time xlab string label X-axis ylab string label Y-axis legend_title string title legend arrow_wt integer weight arrow arrow_color string color arrow

title: Plot periods of events — time_plot_interval
text: plot

title: Plot periods of events — time_plot_interval
code: library(ggplot2) dt = data.frame( id=c('ID01','ID12','ID3'), idn=c(1,3,2), start=1800*c(0,1,2), end=1800*c(2,-1,3), label=c('A','B','C') ) time_plot_interval( dt, xlab='Time', ylab='ID', legend_title='Group', arrow_wt=3, arrow_color='gray')

what: Transformation for continuous data with a finite number of distinct values — trans_composition
title: Transformation for continuous data with a finite number of distinct values — trans_composition
text: trans_composition() derives transformation numerical vector smaller number (ideally < 30) distinct values. return can used function ggplot::scale_x_continuous() ggplot::scale_y_continuous() create desired axis.

title: Transformation for continuous data with a finite number of distinct values — trans_composition
code: trans_composition(x = NULL, nb = 30, brk = NA, dab = NA, dgrd = NA, dgrd2 = NA)

title: Transformation for continuous data with a finite number of distinct values — trans_composition
text: x numerical vector used plot (typically) x nb integer maximum number breaks. Default=30 brk One numerical value within range(x). values value spaced equally NA numerical value greater equal max(x). values plotted original scale numerical value smaller equal max(x). values plotted equal space dab One NA value calculated automatically number distance brk dgrd One NA value calculated automatically number minimum space major grids dgrd2 One NA value calculated automatically number minimum space major grids

title: Transformation for continuous data with a finite number of distinct values — trans_composition
text: transformation function

title: Transformation for continuous data with a finite number of distinct values — trans_composition
code: library(ggplot2) pdt=data.frame(x=rep(c(0.5, 1, 10,11,12, 100, 1000), each=5)) pdt$y=pdt$x+rnorm(length(pdt$x)) t=trans_composition(pdt$x,brk=50, dab=3) ggplot(pdt, aes(x=x, y=y))+geom_point()+scale_x_continuous(trans=t)

what: Transformation for continuous data with a finite number of distinct values — trans_loglinear
title: Transformation for continuous data with a finite number of distinct values — trans_loglinear
text: trans_loglinear() derives log transformation numerical vector smaller number (ideally < 30) distinct values.. return can used function ggplot::scale_x_continuous() ggplot::scale_y_continuous() create desired axis.

title: Transformation for continuous data with a finite number of distinct values — trans_loglinear
code: trans_loglinear(x = NULL, nb = 30, int = NA, scale = NA, mindist = 0.03)

title: Transformation for continuous data with a finite number of distinct values — trans_loglinear
text: x numerical vector used plot (typically) x nb integer maximum number breaks. Default=30 int One NA value calculated automatically real number (>=0) shift log transform scale One NA value calculated automatically real number (>0) scale log transform mindist One NA default value set 0.03 real number 0 0.2 minimum distance ratio major ticks

title: Transformation for continuous data with a finite number of distinct values — trans_loglinear
text: transformation function

title: Transformation for continuous data with a finite number of distinct values — trans_loglinear
code: library(ggplot2) pdt=data.frame(x=rep(c(0.5, 1, 10,11,12, 100, 1000), each=5)) pdt$y=pdt$x+rnorm(length(pdt$x)) t=trans_loglinear(pdt$x) ggplot(pdt, aes(x=x, y=y))+geom_point()+scale_x_continuous(trans=t)
